website_summaries.verdict: The Lenovo ThinkPad Yoga hybrid ultrabook brings the Yoga multimode design to the business-focused ThinkPad lineup. Tablet fans will love it, but the performance isn't quite as good as other ThinkPad models.
pros: Multimode design is a first for the business-focused ThinkPad
Boasts an Intel Core i5-4200U processor, a 128GB SSD, and perks like 802.11AC WLAN and a stylus for high-accuracy tasks

customer_reviews.title: Absolutely love mine
customer_reviews.text: Bought this laptop about a year ago. There's absolutely nothing i can complain about. It's touchscreen, folds backwards into a tablet, contains enough RAM and space for graphic work, and some music production. Wonderful Brand, Great experience, would definitely recommend! *do note that this model does not come with the thinkpad yoga stylus/ pen included. At first i thought i can just buy the thinkpad yoga stylus separately, but it doesn't work on this model (as this model isn't pre-programmed to work with that particular stylus). Any other capacitive stylus/ pen will work just fine though. So it's still an awesome buy :).
customer_reviews.author: Nina long

customer_reviews.title: Practically perfect
customer_reviews.text: Good laptop. Great processor and the touch screen is well integrated with Windows 8. My only complaint is that switching back and forth between tablet and laptop can sometimes get laggy when you are watching a video. Otherwise great. This model does not have the digitizer pen.
customer_reviews.author: Jillian Azares

customer_reviews.title: Great battery life
customer_reviews.text: More than I expected. No fingerprint scanner. Versatile work book. Runs a little hot. Great battery life. It is becoming my workhorse on the road.
customer_reviews.author: Bill Richards

customer_reviews.title: in a good way. It seamlessly works streaming via Chromecast to ...
customer_reviews.text: Really enjoying this laptop. It feels a lot bigger than it is, in a good way. It seamlessly works streaming via Chromecast to my TV with quality (currently streaming a live Avett Brothers concert). The versatility of the screen position is impressive. It is a little heavier that I thought it would be given the size, but it makes it feel durable, so it is not a bad thing. Doesn't get too hot and I can barely hear the fan when it is running.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: I love technical support for this thinkpad
customer_reviews.text: I love technical support for this thinkpad. They speak english. I bought this refurbished. there were some problems. they didn't ask a question, but quickly and efficiently fixed it. if feel very different from my dell...a bit clunky and the keys feel funny..but it works...and is nice and sleek....easy to use...and i like the slightly higher keys...
customer_reviews.author: Cheryl A. Wolverton

customer_reviews.title: Top Notch from the promising thinkpad series
customer_reviews.text: This is the best quality laptop that i have every come across. The build quality it top notch. It is a promising thinkpad. The swivel and keys going in on the back and the processing power and the display is awesome. Also the audio is also really really good for a thinkpad
customer_reviews.author: Sam Jacob Dev

customer_reviews.title: Solid convertible laptop
customer_reviews.text: Great computer. Love using the touch screen in tablet mode. Startup is fast and the battery life is good. It did take me a minute to get used to using windows 8 but I haven't had anything to complain about.
customer_reviews.author: Paul

customer_reviews.title: " Piece of garbage. DO NOT BUY
customer_reviews.text: This computer was made with a faulty motherboard. Lenovo/IBM knew about it but didn't tell anyone. We had it for just over one year, then the motherboard died. This was no cheapie laptop. When I call Lenovo directly, they said "Out of warranty? Out of luck." Piece of garbage. DO NOT BUY!!!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Bad BIOS, bad service.  Bad for serious users.
customer_reviews.text: Back in May, 2014, Lenovo put out a BIOS that messed with the End/insert key, and fn-lock. This made the keyboard pretty much useless for serious technical users (that edit code, etc.) who use the f1-12 keys a lot. Furthermore, on brand new unit, the down-arrow key cap keeps falling off. Lenovo was unwilling, for 5 months straight of knowing about problem, and even after 3 more BIOS releases, to fix the problem.
customer_reviews.author: EmTee
